title: How to Make Plaster of Paris

methods.name: Making Plaster of Paris from Flour

steps.headline: Heat 1 cup (240 ml) to 100 °F (38 °C).
steps.description: Warm water works best to help speed up the process. Use either a microwave or a stove to heat the water to the correct temperature.

steps.headline: Combine the water with 2 cups (256 g) of flour in a mixing bowl.
steps.description: Pour the water over the flour as evenly as you can. Once all the water is added, start stirring the mix with a spoon or spatula. If you’re worried about dried plaster sticking to your utensils, use a disposable plastic spoon.

steps.headline: Stir the mixture with a spatula until there are no lumps.
steps.description: The consistency should be a thick white paste when you’re finished. In the end, the plaster should be thick, but not difficult to stir. If it seems too thick, add more water. If it is too runny, add more flour until it thickens.

steps.headline: Work with the plaster within 10 minutes.
steps.description: You’ll notice the plaster mixture will start to solidify as you work with it. Pour the mixture into your molds as soon as you’ve finished stirring it for the best results.

steps.headline: Let the plaster set for 48 hours.
steps.description: The plaster may seem to dry within 24 hours, but it will not be completely set through. Allow it to sit at room temperature for 2-3 days to dry.

steps.headline: Heat 2 to 3 cups (470 to 710 ml) of water to 100 °F (38 °C).
steps.description: Use a microwave or stove to heat the water to temperature.

steps.headline: Mix 1 cup (240 ml) of water with 2 cups (470 ml) of school glue.
steps.description: Pour the water and glue into a mixing bowl and stir them together thoroughly with a spatula. Stir in a little water at a time until the plaster has a soupy consistency.

steps.headline: Work with the plaster within 15 minutes.
steps.description: Making plaster with glue will make it have a slightly longer drying time, but you should still work with it as soon as you finish mixing it. Pour it into molds to form the shape you want.

steps.headline: Let the plaster set for 48-72 hours.
steps.description: Since plaster with glue takes longer to cure, it make take up to 3 days for the plaster cast to completely dry. Keep it at room temperature for an even and thorough dry.

text: Making Plaster of Paris from Flour Heat 1 cup (240 ml) to 100 °F (38 °C). Warm water works best to help speed up the process. Use either a microwave or a stove to heat the water to the correct temperature. Combine the water with 2 cups (256 g) of flour in a mixing bowl. Pour the water over the flour as evenly as you can. Once all the water is added, start stirring the mix with a spoon or spatula. If you’re worried about dried plaster sticking to your utensils, use a disposable plastic spoon. Stir the mixture with a spatula until there are no lumps. The consistency should be a thick white paste when you’re finished. In the end, the plaster should be thick, but not difficult to stir. If it seems too thick, add more water. If it is too runny, add more flour until it thickens. Work with the plaster within 10 minutes. You’ll notice the plaster mixture will start to solidify as you work with it. Pour the mixture into your molds as soon as you’ve finished stirring it for the best results. Let the plaster set for 48 hours. The plaster may seem to dry within 24 hours, but it will not be completely set through. Allow it to sit at room temperature for 2-3 days to dry. Using Glue Heat 2 to 3 cups (470 to 710 ml) of water to 100 °F (38 °C). Use a microwave or stove to heat the water to temperature. Mix 1 cup (240 ml) of water with 2 cups (470 ml) of school glue. Pour the water and glue into a mixing bowl and stir them together thoroughly with a spatula. Stir in a little water at a time until the plaster has a soupy consistency. Work with the plaster within 15 minutes. Making plaster with glue will make it have a slightly longer drying time, but you should still work with it as soon as you finish mixing it. Pour it into molds to form the shape you want. Let the plaster set for 48-72 hours. Since plaster with glue takes longer to cure, it make take up to 3 days for the plaster cast to completely dry. Keep it at room temperature for an even and thorough dry.
